tW_A0nxvpwMwS4ZGtGMLrA.text: I have been to the Soho branch of this Indian street food chein several times and wouldn't normally choose to eat out in Earls Court. But a 2-for-1 offer is too good to pass and a trip to Soho too much of an efford on a rainy Sunday afternoon.I just love the thali idea of being served a variety of delicious dishes. This latest one consisted of black pepper chicken - delicious and with loads for fresh herbs and spices in evidence - plus coconut potatoes and a lovely mixed vegetable curry, as well as thali, pilau rice, papadom and pickles. A very filling and most delicious meal. We opted for the lassi and chaas which complemented the food perfectly.Admittedly the ambience does not hide the fact that this is a fast food outlet, but this type is of the highest quality and a lot more interesting than food at a similar price.They are currently running a 2-for-1 deal which unfortunately will expire on 9 December.

0sejtGNejlAa_gU5hseVLg.text: Masala Zone!  How I miss thee!!  We ate here almost everyday during our stay.  Good food.  Close to the Underground.  Quick service.  And not very pricey.

emKD9kQyyIkbete4qjvn0g.text: I really like this Indian restaurant. The food is good and affordable. Also the service is friendly. I like to order the plates with different sauces and vegetables. The restaurant is accessible and they have disabled facilities. You can't reach all tables without steps.

tYqsNX1a3tv9FEFQi8APCg.text: I really wanted to like this place but I couldn't find much flavor in the food.  I ordered the vegetable curry thali with naan.  The flavor of every dish is muted, including the curry.  Even the naan was disappointing.  The texture was all off -- too crumbly instead of stretchy. The best dish on the thali was the dal.   I won't be coming back.

W5S1P3qbXjeoBuDxwISHZw.text: The best Indian yogurt sauce that I ever had. I consider the thail (combination plate) a very good starter choice because you can try a few of the side dishes. Delicious and healthy, I guess in my own mind.

9qtXF-Gj7GWF7pqWcJmkAg.text: So good! Definitely get the Thali but you can't go wrong with any of their dishes. Makes me hungry just thinking about it!

CxjWU5id_qemdkrYYBoJ8A.text: Extremely good value for Indian food.

photos.caption: Photo of Masala Zone Earls Court - London, United Kingdom

zkYLIrr4r3IaaLDUqhxDQg.text: I have just been to this Masala Zone restaurant, and things have changed for the worst....When they first opened I was quite impressed with the modern, contemporary decor and the interesting menu. But I am afraid that the quality of the food has become really disappointing.The curries are very powdery, the naan breads are dry (feels like they have been waiting around for a while).Something particularly annoying with the Earls Court branch: the bottled drinks are very warm - whether it's water or red wine you are ordering. So you end up having to put ice cubes to cool things down - which is ok for water but less brilliant for red wine. Still nice decor, but even at the reasonable prices the food is poor value for money.

nEAnAT_VT3H2PIOuCBYbVQ.text: Nice place for a first encounter with an Indian restaurant. Nice food also take away. Friendly staff, just a nice place to go to

jbr7nRESRbdAlgFAdh7ycA.text: I've eaten here a few times, the food has always been top notch. It can appear fairly pricey when everything is ordered separately from the menu. I would recommend having your chosen main as a Thali - the meal comes with rice, a naan and a few other side dishes all on one 'tray' the service is fast and the staff are friendly and helpful. The restaurant is large enough to accomodate a large group, it's always been easy to get a table.

lq5cJON0eXh94_ItBNzoZQ.text: I was staying in London for one night and this was one of the closest restaurants to my hotel so I thought of give it a go. On the outside, the restaurant looked very stylish, warm and inviting and reasonably busy. Upon entering we were showed to a table within moments by friendly staff. The decor was bright and contemporary with interesting touches like the suspended bamboo ceiling and clever lighting. The menu selection was impressive. Many dishes I hadn't seen in other Indian restaurants were featured. The service was excellent, staff were very attentive. The food arrived reasonably promptly was delicious, full of flavour and spice. We were even able to use a discount card which gave us up to 50% off despite it being Valentines day! Our bill total came to a very impressive £22 including service charge. On the whole, I highly rate this restaurant and would recommend it to anyone in the area and beyond. They have several branches across London and assume you will receive a similar experience at their other locations.

BsuSM6J8VuCNFSVBMxwFlQ.text: A great place to eat when you fancy a good Indian meal! easy and convenient and the food is tasty!

LnIo5fZfr7UQDZsIuWAySA.text: Visited on Wednesday last week, and had a great spicy starter with chickpeas, followed by a thali. Couldn't fault the food. It was great, and more traditional Indian than you usually find in the typical British any house. The only fault I could find would be the Cobra beer. I prefer Kingfisher. Although this isn't a big issue.

fSYnUXCCw4YYLb-4GkM2eg.text: I agree with the previous reviewer about the set menu -- it is overpriced and the choice is poor. However the a la carte selection is very broad and also extremely good value for money. Food is usually presented on a thali, with rice, chipatti/naan, a curry of your choice, as well as three smaller dishes (dahls, etc.) that the chefs change every day. It's a fantastic way to eat for £8-£10. Having said all this, you are by no means obligated to eat from a thali; you can order food presented in a more common anglo-indian fashion if you prefer. The two curries I've tried at Masala Zone are butter chicken and rogan josh. In both cases the curries were properly spiced and the meat was extremely tender but still well cooked. I was particularly impressed by the lamb. The starters are very tasty but perhaps not as good value as the thalis. Aloo tikka chaat, and the dabalrotis in particular are worth trying. Masala Zone is very attractive inside; the are deep red and brown murals on the walls and pleasant lighting. The atmosphere is very relaxed and there is always a diverse mix of people there. The service is prompt and polite (though perhaps a bit unreliable at times). Later in the evenings it can get pretty busy, but I would consider this a good thing. If you arrive before 6.30pm then you have the option of a cheaper set menu. Don't be afraid of not being able to get a table later on -- as long as you arrive before 8pm there shouldn't be a problem. It can be very difficult to find a good indian restaurant in London; I've been caught out many times by indian restaurants that look good from the outside, but are in fact overpriced with poor food and service. Masala Zone is, on the other hand, reliable, original and very good value.

i9sQbp-vA_s3L4YgJpkjbg.text: I tried it a while ago and didn't like anything.The atmosphere, noise and lack of space was like a canteen.The service was friendly.The choice and taste of the food was also pretty bad. Sipping my warm Coke I gave up after half of the portion, walked to the Delhi Brasserie round the corner im Cromwell Rd. and - relaxed happily.How interesting and what a blessing that we are so different.

jJdo6458WYWW8nvLYLKfUA.text: Masala Zone has branches in Soho and Islington as well as in Earls Court. All serve the most delicious authentic Indian food from street food dishes to curry and rice, noodles to thalis (whole meals on a tray). Prices rarely go above £12 per person with drinks and it is often just £8-10. The staff are friendly and attentive and are more than happy to guide you through the menu if you have any queries. Highly recommended

9MCMbpjjakaR1wAqg694kw.text: I visited this place two months ago with a group of friends for a 30th birthday celebration. Not the best indian i have tasted but still very good indian food. Their curries were deliciously spicy without being overwhelming. My friend who is diabetic was able to find something in their menu structured for a diabetic. Good variety of indian food and good service. You donot need to make a reservation unless in a party of ten.Currently there is a 2 for 1 promotion valid from sunday to thursday upto the 9th of december 2008 for two customers. This promotion is only for those eating in and excludes food to go and home delivery orders. prices usually start from about £9 per head.

ZauTMc9bqY9GU4Xcp_mK-A.text: Fairly new chain of modern Indian restaurants; we have eaten several times at the Earl's Court location.Food is good value, atmosphere nice and relaxed, but service can be a bit patchy (although always with a smile). Good option for dinner with friends.

qqbHTy5znNvXtJ2TUYDRWA.text: The difference between Curry houses and authentic Indian joints are that the latter is much closer to the food that you get in India. Masala Zone is one such place thats spicier than the average curry house but hey, the fact is Indian food can also be spicy. However, this branch at Earl's court is one of the better Indian restaurants (the food is authentic Indian and is not a poor curry replica). The sweets (especially the rasmalai) are exactly the same as you get in India and overall the prices are at honest to goodness levels. Overall, excellent choice and a must visit. There could be bad days of service, but I've visited more than a couple of times and they have been consistently good.

vfbxZqji83PfFXGaQDR97g.text: Food was EXCELLENT! Loved the traditional way of serving several dishes at once. This restaurant is Austin try

VXND2WwdEAZp08SGIDi0pA.text: Each time I've stayed in Kensington, I've had at least one meal at Masala Zone since it's only about a block away from where I stay. The good: The thalis are a great -- ample amount of food, good flavors and a fair price. The appetizers are also quite tasty. The staff has always been pleasant.The bad: Spice-wise, it's a bit on the mild side. The tikka masala is a bit blah, sadly. Stick with the thalis or the apps and you'll be good to go. Is it the best Indian food I've ever had? Not even close. But, if you are in a rush or not in the mood to go far, it's a nice option.

t9dKtjvpRAgUwbGtSXaj5A.text: Was on the lookout for Mai Food but, after regretfully forgetting where it was, I ended up at Masala Zone. Despite being skeptical of chain restaurants, the menu looked pretty decent, so I decided to give it a go.Overall, I'd say the food was good, not great. I started with the dahi puri biscuits, which I thought had good flavor, but most of it was drowning in yogurt. Then I tried the butter chicken curry, which had decent flavor but a disappointing amount of chicken.It was a good meal, but I definitely wasn't doing cartwheels out of the restaurant.

l7i12UYS_GbgoTe7Wve_Ig.text: I love this place.  I love that you get a little taste of many dishes.  There's something spicy, something sweet.  I usually get the vegetarian or lamb varieties.  I've been a few times spread out over a few different visits to London and the food has been good each time.   The service is good and the decor nice.

h1Ww_V8SphPimCginjH_zg.text: Excellent food.  Was really tasty and well presented.   Excellent service - quick and efficient service. I'm gluten free and the staff were helpful and knowledgeable (yay) whilst my two dining companions didn't feel limited. The gluten free options were wide ranging for the mains.  Worth a visit.

atZFdrM3OzDl8H76JSl06Q.text: The chicken tikka is flavorful but not overpowering, and very moist. The garlic naan and mango lassi are also delicious! The service was prompt and friendly, and the atmosphere is fun and cozy, even in such a busy area as Earl's Court. I do wish the portions were a bit larger for how much they are charging, though.

_UHStjYMrasXwQP-sgw15g.text: Ate here for dinner. Food was tasty but had a problem with the hygiene in the restaurant. I noticed that the cooks place the order slip in the food when it's ready. Also the cooks and waitresses handled the naan bread with their hands. I just think that hygiene should be better. I also thought that the meat portions were a little small.

Tbpgevokh5cSAhhuPHyvTQ.text: Food was fine. I went with family. They thought food was fine. I thought Malabar green Chicken is AMAZING. Horrible service though. Asked for coffee before meal, got it during and had to wait till after. At least it was free then. Slow service all the way through: Order, get food, pay bill. Spices were not great. Food was decent fare, but I've seen better.

JArKcK6QAtTvMsPrX9VQig.text: Not spicy enough which makes it less authentic. The thali was good but I didn't like the butter chicken. For me anything that's spicy is good. I don't think I'll go again. Also I have made better sweet lassi. Very average. Staff was good, like other reviews I didn't find the service slow.

yNKXRXw4sKA55-jVCLw-eQ.text: An excellent Indian restaurant in London with somewhat fair prices. The food is very good - I had a Thali plate with butter chicken curry and a variety of other stuff, all of which was very tasty. The service was also very good, all of our waiters were very polite. Only downside are the opening times - we were frequently standing in front of the restaurant, half-starved, but quite often had to leave because they were closed during most of the afternoon. If that hadn't been the case, we'd probably have eaten here every day instead of just once!

cmFfLsIIgkQkrzA_RakpHg.text: I know it's a chain, but I'm a huge fan of Masala Zone.  This is primarily down to their authentic and interesting menu and focus on thali dishes.They had a wide range of lunch offers - we took them up on a starter & thali 2 course menu (for around £9.50).  The 'street food' style starters were tasty and interesting (if basic) and the thalis never fail with their mixed selection of curries, rice & breads etc.The service was fairly standard - not quick, but not slow either.  One point of note was the added 10% service charge.  We paid it, feeling it was deserved, but I would rather the tipping decision was left to me.

wl-_9TvYlYPaExTcw2QFcw.text: It's a chain, but the food is very good value for money and also tasty. Try the early-bird special thali plate for a chance to try a lot of dishes for not very much money. I tried chicken tikka masala which was respectable though definitely not the best I've had.If you need a quick meal that you know will be good and don't want to pay a huge amount, this is a solid bet.Gluten-free notes: This is an Indian restaurant, so most of the dishes are naturally gluten-free.

waCCsahUlSw2vwN6ZIO-uw.text: A place you can get a nice curry without all your clothes smelling curry when you leave! I had rosh mild lamb curry which was very good. Very friendly& nice staff.

pRq3u4iKxEEVkaUtvrWRVA.text: Looking into this restaurant window I saw a calm, inviting setting even though it was at its busiest. It took about 5 minutes to get a table and the staff were friendly. We got a table for two at the back of the restaurant. I was pleased to see that the waitresses weren't annoyed at our indecisiveness as they had to come back several times. The platter for two came as a starter and in perfect portions, the waitress was kind enough to introduce the plate, if only all restaurants did this! She seemed passionate about the food and it really rubbed off on us as we tucked in. A big 10/10 for service!The food was served in good portions although a bit pricey. They were kind enough to give us a student discount after asking however only took about £3 off the total bill of £40 which I thought was a little stingy. Overall a nice style of restaurant but if the price was more affordable I would give it a 10.

ag6-yGlddlB0FPO2r8Uvqw.text: The food here was good but the service was not that great at all. Two of my friends fell asleep at the table waiting for our check to come. We had the lunch special and the portions were large enough and the food seemed fresh. i would come again but just ask for the bill while ordering.

CfkyYg6WEwgQJ1LKoNS1NA.text: Went here while visiting London and came back once more. It is definitely one of the better options in Earls Court if trying to find something other than a pub. It has a much more authentic flavor than most Indian food I've tried in the states. Given how expensive most restaurants are in London this one is fairly reasonable.

r0QSzEh6Saxo4ZlHBKxm6A.text: I stopped into Masala Zone with my visiting brother expecting to get a reliably tasty curry before sending him on his way home.  The place was completely buzzing at 9pm, with only a few tables left available, which in my opinion is a good sign.  We received appropriately prompt service and were left to peruse the menu.  All good.Sadly, the food left me feeling apathetic.  I did not relish every delicious bite of my thali, because, well, it wasn't as delicious as it usually is at Masala Zones.  Everything felt and tasted a bit commercialised and affected.  Was it because Masala Zone's chain mentality is getting the best of it?  Was it an issue of Masala Zone Earl's Court bowing under the weight of its own seeming popularity?  The food was average, at best, and mostly uninspiring.  And there were no onion bhajis on the menu - wtf.In any event, the 'Masala Coke' I ordered was foul.  No matter how delicious the menu makes Coke with crushed mint and spices sound to you, don't be fooled.  It tasted sort of like a Bloody Mary without the vodka and Coke subbed for tomato. MISTAKE.

6X23E9Pnz13lDAH82At68A.text: The food is good here. Its going to be 50% more expensive than your run of the mill indian restaurant. The service is slow but its also a nicer ambiance than the regular indian restaurant. If you are in the mood for a leisurely well made indian dinner, and don't mind paying a little more,  this is the place to go. Its all about your expectations. They added a 12.5% obligatory tip. I thought that was on the high end. I can understand 10%. Plus the service really is slow so it grates a bit.  However, as I said earlier, if you can go in the right expectations on price, you will like this place. I would recommend it for its good food, and decent decor/ambiance.

-b-aH3PdFJ-C_vTBhmEQJA.text: I have to say that for a chain the food and service were excellent. I would not hesitate to come back.

wMN7m9ROOpduV7uzP5baHA.text: When it comes to Indian food and other such spice-laden cuisines I am a bit of a lightweight since I can barely hack the intensity provided by too much pepper but I am slowly getting to grips with this disability (with gentle encouragement from the missus) and places like this really push me to keep trying.The menu has quite a lot to offer and the waiter was incredibly helpful, explaining what some of the less common dishes were and, crucially, just how much spice was involved.  The food was awesome and though it was somewhat on the threshold of my spice tolerance I soldiered on like the champion I am and thoroughly enjoyed my meal.I think if you go before 6:30pm there is a slighlty cheaper meal option but even if you miss it the prices won't break your bank.  Defintely a solid choice for a pleasant, affordable meal.

RmjMXfqbtxTW-angn6Vehg.text: My wife wanted Some good Indian food but she didn't get it here. It was great Indian food. Very flavorful and well prepared. The staff was friendly and courteous. We will certainly dine here again if we make it back to Kensington.

80I0zY5Qo5kGPpnJml_FKA.text: I just absolutely loved this place.  The decor was artsy, modern and colorful. They had a great selection of Thali's which is a selection of foods on a big metal tray including meats ( or vegetarian dishes ) or both, naan or chapati, pappadam, sauces, rice and dal for a decent price from 11 to 15 English pounds. I choice the Madras Railway chicken which had a brown cinnamon spice creamy sauce that was lovely. The Butter Chicken was also a yummy flavorful delight. The dal was perfect, slightly runny and filled with herbs, the garlic naan was not too garlicy so I would beg for cheese naan next time ( although it says you can only substitute garlic or plain naan for your chapati for a supplement of 1-2 English Pounds.Unfortunately our group of 7 had to be seated at 2 different tables so call ahead if you have a big group. This is a chain restaurant that doesn't feel like a chain. I have traveled to India and this place rivals the flavors from my trip yet not the price (of course)!I am planning on eating here every time I visit London.

photos.caption: Photo of Masala Zone Earls Court - London, United Kingdom

koUuLPTzIA0B-egiCJ8b_w.text: Food and service were great. We had the samosas and the Thali as well as one other dish I can't remember the name of.

ibWiCWIrQI7CuDb7mvyT1w.text: Came in after a long flight and saw the advertisement for Masala Zone @ Earl's Court Station. It was across the street from the station, one block over. Staff was courteous and kind.  Outside the mandatory discretionary service fee, great place to dine. One of the best north Indian dishes I've had.  Ordered the chicken mangalore, with garlic naan and rice...was fantastic!  I like spicy foods and this didn't disappoint. It was full of flavor that wasn't overwhelmed by the spice

photos.caption: Photo of Masala Zone Earls Court - London, United Kingdom. Chicken Mangalore with garlic naan and rice

ZWPQD1hSSSL_gJWh8hh6CA.text: This used to be a favorite of mine in London. Updated tasty Indian food. As I arrived in London yesterday I was eager to go there again. I don't know whether the management has changed, but my experience was less than good. The rich flavors I remembered had gone, replaced by some bland versions of Indian food. The waiting time between the starter and the main dish was 25 minutes!

1pKAkucB5vJ4F3MRYCXNWg.text: Love Masala Zone. The most stand-out place in the cluster of restaurants near the Earl's Court station, in my opinion. It's tough to beat the value of their regular/grand Thalis, which lets you sample a number of curries and veggie dishes via their colorful palette of piping-hot tastiness. Stayed in this area on vacation and ended up eating here two of three nights. Authentic food, open late, friendly service. The interior is very lively with sound of many languages representing the diverse London population. Wish they'd expand their chain to the States :D

photos.caption: Photo of Masala Zone Earls Court - London, United Kingdom. Regular Thali

HPikqYMAbr4QbE1eBlOKlQ.text: Masala Zone is an Indian restaurant with several locations around London. I visited the Earls Court location and really enjoyed the experience. The atmosphere of this place made me feel like I was back in India with the dark setting and the aroma from the kitchen.   We ordered a variety of starters including the Sev Puri and Dahi Puri.  They were all delicious and I could have eaten it all by myself! For my main course, I chose the thali which is a traditional Indian platter loaded with little bowls of various treats.  Everything I tried was good.  The most amusing thing for me about this place is fact that they had Masala Coke.  I first had a Masala Coke in Delhi, India.  I remember tasting this creation on the streets of Delhi thinking that my friends had pulled a joke on me.  It was quite possibly the worst thing I'd ever tasted.  So when I saw this rancid thing on the menu here at Masala Zone, I realized that my friends back in India had not pulled a joke on me.  I had to try it again here at Masala Zone and while it still wasn't very good, it was a lot better than the one I had back in Delhi.  4 stars for Masala Coke and making me feel like I was back in India.

y3L2-WJN7Z2SU5Uk20aX5Q.text: Love every visit to this place. Only minus is the time they take to serve food. They can also work a little bit on their service.. On taking out empty plates, replacing cutlery etc. Not really the bang for the buck types, but for a subtle evening with friends n family if you crave some authentic mild Indian food !

-lLnovA1aizikAVgQQXZTw.text: Lovely lunch this afternoon at Masala Zone. The staff was nice and the food was very tasty! I never had a veg thali before so I was intrigued when the waiter recommended it to me. It was perfect because I wanted a variety of flavors and that's exactly what I got! I definitely recommend this place for a quick lunch when you need to get back to the office within an hour.

photos.caption: Photo of Masala Zone Earls Court - London, United Kingdom. Yummy!

L3cgBjMxsJXBhC4dgIAWOA.text: Overall, decent Indian food at an almost decent price. Service was poor as we could never figure out who our waiter really was and our appetizer arrived well after our dinners were served.

Pj-uzgHtdqOQHPUY65ENrw.text: Friendly and attentive staff, generous with the wine pour and enjoyed every bit of my meal..I had the Thali with lamb curry delish

MIrK6GHehc3rVSpCJR0fBA.text: This was my first real Indian food experience in London so I was just impressed with the step change improvement of taste, variety, ambiance and service of Indian cuisine compared to the US. Everything was great and would go there again.

B8mt1V8eWebQY8UK6ptC4A.text: I missed the strong indian spices. I love indian food, but I could make better indian at home. My boyfriend had hair in his food. The portions where a bit small. Naan bread was thin and not tasty. The tip wasnt optional, it was added 12% eventho we didnt want to add. Bad experience.

QtNfgSk0OrPs87Lj-KopXQ.text: over priced for what you get. Lacking in good service and flavor. No chicken tikka masala

76KUr8b9h1QzoVQ1e1wH0Q.text: Very mediocre and somewhat bland indian food. The prices are not too bad for london. We got the regular thali, which has a choice of curry in small size, with a couple of side dishes on a silver platter, and then a curry with rice. I don't remember the names of the two types of curries we got but they were both of the spicy nature and they weren't that spicy. The quantity of the curry on regular thali is actually pretty small and we didnt really like all the side dishes that came with. I wasn't impressed.

XBSIN2qvcQ_1Z78rJ-dZeA.text: Finally, I found an Indian restaurant in London that didn't  try to overcharge, extra charge, or, false advertising of a happy hour.Floor staffs were efficient and knowledgeable, friendly and courteous. And the food here was excellent. They have good selection of wine, too. I recommend this place to those who are not too expert on Indian cuisine. There are many located through London. My favorite is Earls Court location. I suggest to avoid those individually operated Indian Restaurants if you are not local. They will most likely try to cheat. It's not a good way to end your meal if you have to doubt the bill and question about it.

FgerNpqYg3gfVMUP6NflTQ.text: This place is okay.. but not the best. You will be paying quite a bit for a so-so experience. The service couldn't be better.. it's almost too good with the people who work here checking every 5 seconds if you are enjoying your food. But in the end the food just wasn't that great and you'd be far better off seeking out a cheaper and more authentic experience.If you do go here I recommend the appetizers and veggie dishes. The butter chicken and paneer tikka masala were both pretty disappointing. I can't even put my finger on what they were missing, but they were definitely lacking something. At first I thought it was just me but my boyfriend noticed right away too. We've frequented some amazing Indian restaurants in NYC, San Diego, + LA and my boyfriend has traveled through India so I think we have a good enough background to tell..Now I know tikka masala isn't "real" food from India, but we do like it a lot and heard London is of course the place to have it.. I guess that added to our disappointment. Like I said, go for the veggie based stuff and the more India-based dishes. Large thali can be shared with 2 people, although they didn't seem very happy to do this even though we also ordered a large appetizer. Veg dishes are worth at least a 4-5 star rating, but those tikka masala dishes are definitely in the 2 star range. My boyfriend did enjoy his "Masala Coke" although I found it to be kind of gross!

KdXqKSwwN3qt7t-GSsAOWw.text: We have been to this restaurant twice in the last 6 weeks while on holidays. Both times the service has been outstanding as has the food. The atmosphere was great and all the staff were extremely friendly and made our dinner special. We would highly recommend eating here, the good is very tasty!!

1Sof2RvNB2VOSuELQrJ7aw.text: Providing very affordable, good-quality Indian cuisine, Masala Zone is a venture of the more up-market Chutney Mary chain. The service when I have been there has been very fast - it can get very busy, and is a bit noisy, so not really a place to linger for a romantic meal for two - but great if you want some decent Indian food. Recent lunch experiences have been very good - they do a two-course option for £7.95, so you can get a decent, varied meal, with a drink, for about a tenner. This certainly adds depth to the stock of restaurants in Earl's Court, which was lacking a good Indian.

photos.caption: Photo of Masala Zone Earls Court - London, United Kingdom

uwWzg3mzYAkCAHO8wniy6Q.text: Food was bland and portions were unbelievably small.  I brought with me two people who had never eaten indian food and asked the waitress to describe some of the dishes - she instead described the layout of the bizarrly laid out menu and left me to teach the diners about the food!Service was mediocre - i told the waitress of my two food allergies (mango and cilantro/coriander leaf) and the plate still had the mango chuntney and the garnish.. I removed them and tried to eat. it was soo bland it just tasted like chicken gravy instead of a curry! poor poor food, esp for the costThe salted lassi with cumin was good.

RJf56eL6zBMGbHeo0d7Xow.text: I wasn't expecting super homemade authentic curry here but it met my expectations. A bit pricey for what you get -- if you order only curry you also have to get a side of rice, naan, or another accompaniment. I had the butter chicken thali which was good -- nice to have an assortment of dishes to try. Also had the raspberry mojito which was good but not outstanding. I'm not sure how other Indian restaurants arrange and price their menus but being from the States I had an expectation that at least rice would be included with a main dish.That said you probably can't go wrong with anything on the menu here -- definitely a good find!

photos.caption: Photo of Masala Zone Earls Court - London, United Kingdom. Raspberry mojito.
Photo of Masala Zone Earls Court - London, United Kingdom. Butter chicken thali with a side of garlic naan.

fYuVz8c4quJPpA5A24slFg.text: Without a doubt this is the worst Indian food I have ever tasted.  The Rogan Josh was watery and just bland.  The Thali is a rip off as the curry is less than half a cup in measure, the rest is just condiments that you would normally get at any Indian restaurant.  The rice was an over cooked wet mess.I was really disappointed.  One further note, the food is not cooked to order and the chef is literally serving the food from a ban buree.  I watched the chef wipe down the counter top and then wipe down the Thali platter with the same rag cloth and then proceed to serve food directly on the platter he just wiped.Save your money and go to a traditional Indian restaurant where they actually care about what they are serving and how they serve it.

rnDEA9VLCkwGLTk7Xr5_TA.text: This was my first visit to Masala Zone.  We went there with a couple of friends.   We had a reservation for a Sat afternoon. I ordered the Chaas (spiced lassi) from the drink menu-  It was average. I felt the mixture of spices used did not liven up the lassi as it should have.  For starters, I ordered a festival special (Jalebi chaat).  I thought it was going to be sweet but it was interesting with a savory shaped in the form of a jalebi.  For the main course, I ordered Khichadi and Undhiyo instead of a Thali.  Masala Zone offers a variety of Thali options ( Veg, Prawn, Lamb, Chicken). The version of Khichadi and Undhiyo served here was very different from the ones I have had in typical Gujarathi places.  The Khichadi was drier than what I am used to (had the consistency closer to a pulao).  The Undhiyo had the typical vegetables that one uses but the masala was again different than the ones I have had earlier ( again a drier version with coconut and not as sweet or spicy).  Nevertheless, it was good.All in all a decent experienceAmbience: GoodNoise: Quiet (on a Sat afternoon)Food: Fresh and had an interesting SpinService: pleasant staff but service was very slow on a Sat afternoon though it was not crowded.Recommend it: Worth trying

photos.caption: Photo of Masala Zone Earls Court - London, United Kingdom. Jalebi chaat (festival special)
Photo of Masala Zone Earls Court - London, United Kingdom. Undhiyo

PxJ0ts5OlDbQUpRSPRs4uw.text: Fourth time I'm going to Masala zone restaurants but the first time in the Earl Court's one!The decoration is pretty similar to the other Masala Zones restaurant, but a little bit darker and cosy than the previous ones I visited.The service was good and fast, even if the waiter pushed a bit for us to order appetizers (and we didn't order any)I ordered a very spicy and delicious one this time the Hyderabadi meal: some baby aubergines in a very spicy sauce with some pieces of ginger. I ordered some steam rice on the side. It was really tasty and spicy as I was expecting !Masala zone is good restaurant to go when you want Indian food and you are not sure about the other places around.

hjZtEMGMlE1B-BuWAPk6cg.text: One thing I wanted to eat in London was Indian food since I heard that it is really good. We were so excited when we found Masala Zone. We just happened upon it while walking down the street and did not regret our decision. The food and drinks were absolutely delicious! There were so many great things that I had never had before. The service was a little slow, but the food made up for it!

kA2j_ik3KI4FrzdmrlQBJw.text: It's got a trendy, modern ambiance and the dishes are flavorful with portions just the right size! Husband ordered the butter chicken thali meal with rice and a side of garlic naan + a glass of Johnny Walker - delicious Indian comfort food! I ordered the green chicken curry with basmati rice and a Coca Cola - herbaceous with a strong coriander note and very satisfying! Enjoyed our dessert: brownie and chai! Left very full and happy

photos.caption: Photo of Masala Zone Earls Court - London, United Kingdom. Dessert: brownie with vanilla ice cream and chai
Photo of Masala Zone Earls Court - London, United Kingdom. Towards the front of the restaurant
Photo of Masala Zone Earls Court - London, United Kingdom. Intimate dinner setting for two

gJrVoYi3kd_-rA9tuOjuFA.text: Really good Indian food! Everything was flavorful and delicious! The service was the only thing making it 4 not 5 stars. Make reservations.

photos.caption: Photo of Masala Zone Earls Court - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Masala Zone Earls Court - London, United Kingdom. Butter chicken thali regular

6TQ4NrBalze-V8hA0VkQhQ.text: Great value in the combo platter with curry of your choice, lentils, veggies, rice and potatoes.  I had the non spicy chicken curry which was so flavorful and filling.  Everything was spot on.  My dining companion had one of the curries with 2 chili peppers next to the description and it was super spicy.  She even has a high tolerance for spicy.

photos.caption: Photo of Masala Zone Earls Court - London, United Kingdom

VJy-tO4Nb77WYxGAp3DYdw.text: Food is really good. Portions are fine but if you're like me and is grain free then you'd definite need a side and/or appetizer.  Spinach garlic side is amazing! Ambiance is nice. Service is very good and fast. Definitely the place to go if in Earl's Court

JAFhK7hNhnuy4VoDiOZmDQ.text: Definitely WAY overpriced. £5.50 for the samosa?! Ridiculous! The flavor isn't great either. I have had way tastier and cheaper Indian food elsewhere!

7cSVLfj2sSBH15eyDxPtag.text: Awesome food! Small cozy little restaurant, that also offers take out! The service was a little slow, but worth the wait! Great indian food!! And prize was affordable!

4fGVx-JYD6sEQAY1roQnpg.text: Kind knowledgeable staff. Good location.  Talented chef and kitchen crew.  Smallish dining room. Open for lunch and then reopens for dinner.  Options for veg and non veg with clearly labeled items.  Only downside is somewhat smaller portions and also that rice is an extra charge.  Don't miss those awesome samosas.

photos.caption: Photo of Masala Zone Earls Court - London, United Kingdom. Dining room

ktVieUPKEcfb-MQUFDMJow.text: Masala Zone smells good from the outside. Service is friendly but slow. Food is fine.... but I can't remember what I had because it took soooo long to come. It was about 45 - 50 minutes from when we ordered. So, 4 stars for the food. Minus 3 because I left feeling like I'd wasted my time. They apologized for being slow, but then took 10 minutes to get their card reader after dropping off the bill.

oQfl_JN9HRo5kBy4j4SZSg.text: Very bad experience.Rice - obviously a key element of a curry - was an overcooked clumpy mess.  Completely inedible.Butter chicken a bit heavy on tomato sauce - I didn't hate it, my bud did.  Lamb rogan josh was OK - more a soup with meat than a curryDal was terrible - tomato skins floating around as was a large piece of pappadam which made me wonder if it was reused from another table (doubtful, but unnerving).Veggie side things (potatoes and broccoli in some heavy cream sauce) were not touched; completely overcooked.  Service was OK but every dish was brought by a different employee and no single person took ownership of our table.  Very bad management.I complained and the waitress thought I was making a joke.  The only joke made was how shit this place was - and that was sadly unintentional.Even after they reduced the bill (no kudos to them, I was adamant), it was still overpriced.  Surprised they're still in business - useless.  And rather than talk to us about our poor experience they passed us a card with a link - asking me to log in to their website to relate my concerns.With Dishoom in the market I don't see how these jokers haven't tried to up their game. Clearly the group understand the restaurant business (Veeraswamy, Chutney Mary, Amaya), but its as if they're letting their entry-level spot just fizzle and die.

jcNMaRbRRKc03ueR6maEQg.text: My husband and I are in London on holiday and wanted to have some great Indian food. We got here at 9 pm and it was busy and had gluten free options so we decided to try it out. In the end, the service was fast, but the food was subpar. The curry was not well flavored, the rice was cold and dry, and not included in the price of the curry. I felt that it was overpriced for the quality and quantity of the food. In the end we left disappointed.

wlQehORQCbJzdQJmN3LeGQ.text: We're pretty far away from the kind of modern, polished & intimate boutique restaurants I generally like, but my experience here was clearly 5 stars when it comes to the quality of the food. We went for the regular round platter (Thali) inspired by india's real street food...looking around us, there were actually a few indians in the room, and that's always a good sign right? Well yes it definitely was. My Rogan Josh was perfectly spiced & cooked, and so was my wife's Chicken Butter, 2 pretty classic dishes, but (Rogan) Gosh!, this was out of this world...the chutney, the dhal...everything was just amazing. Oh, did I tell you I really liked it? :) Anyway, I wrote a review on a famous indian restaurant that is victims of its own success (well, not really victim, you're the victim waiting 2 hours in the queue), and this is exactly what I was talking about...those indian restaurants that offer amazing quality at reasonable price, well Masala Zone is spot on. Yes it's a chain, no it's not intimate, but for good casual indian food, this is my spot.

photos.caption: Photo of Masala Zone Earls Court - London, United Kingdom. Rogan Josh Thali!!!

Fhb6Cw4B6Fkyzshyba81Lg.text: With all the amazing indian places in London I would definitely give this place a miss. I've even had better indian food in America. The location itself is nice and the place is rather large and modern looking. The service also isn't bad and they serve you your food quickly. But the quality of the food isn't up to par. I really wanted to like this place as I live nearby but it just didn't hit the mark.I also think that it is a bit overpriced for the portions and quality.

HVZZlVmoPxQXZtvqDsjaCw.text: Food was great.  The service was slow but excellent.  They took effort to see to all our needs.  I would come back.

x2dLzvVU-C-Z4i8vSCAz7g.text: Masala Zone is a small group of restaurants I first encountered a few years back. This one lives up to expectations, and I enjoyed my several recent visits. Great location too.

6I_uQIG8O5VJvWwxJXWPmA.text: Great service and atmoshere. Lovely spot for tasty food and friendly gathering. This place gets busy if you decide to go during peak hours, reservations are suggested. I went early in the evening with a friend and it was great. A must try for Indian food.

photos.caption: Photo of Masala Zone Earls Court - London, United Kingdom. Chicken Thali
